> If a valid URI does not convey any authority (ie: the client must
> be authenticated to use it), there is no need to worry about
> "discovery" of valid URIs. From a security point of view, you
> should assume that if your URIs are guessable, the attacker has
> already guessed them.

Hmm, but from security point of view, you should not provide
functionality to verify that "guess". That is why you simply
get "login failed" instead of "invalid username" or "invalid
password" when you try to login UNIX system (at least, recent
ones). By returning 404 or 401, you're providing extra one bit
of information.

But since this is only a security restriction, I don't think
there's any REST constraint on this policy. It's up to the
implementor. If you think that bit of information is valuable
for RESTful interaction of the Web, then it should be free to
do so.
